Multireference Alignment is Easier with an Aperiodic Translation Distribution

Emmanuel Abbe The Program in Applied and Computational Mathematics, Princeton University, Princeton, NJ, USA Electrical Engineering Department, Princeton University, Princeton, NJ, USA Tamir Bendory The Program in Applied and Computational Mathematics, Princeton University, Princeton, NJ, USA William Leeb The Program in Applied and Computational Mathematics, Princeton University, Princeton, NJ, USA JoÃ£o M. TB, WL, JP, NS, and AS were partially supported by Award Number R01GM090200 from the NIGMS, the Simons Foundation Investigator Award and Simons Collaboration on Algorithms and Geometry, the Moore Foundation Data-Driven Discovery Investigator Award, AFOSR FA9550-17-1-0291 and NSF BIGDATA Award IIS-1837992. Abstract

In the multireference alignment model, a signal is observed by the action of a random circular translation and the addition of Gaussian noise. The goal is to recover the signalâ€™s orbit by accessing multiple independent observations. Of particular interest is the sample complexity, i.e., the number of observations/samples needed in terms of the signal-to-noise ratio (the signal energy divided by the noise variance) in order to drive the mean-square error (MSE) to zero. Previous work showed that if the translations are drawn from the uniform distribution, then, in the low SNR regime, the sample complexity of the problem scales as Ï‰â€‹(1/SNR3)ğœ”1superscriptSNR3\omega(1/\operatorname{SNR}^{3}). In this work, using a generalization of the Chapmanâ€“Robbins bound for orbits and expansions of the Ï‡2superscriptğœ’2\chi^{2} divergence at low SNR, we show that in the same regime the sample complexity for any aperiodic translation distribution scales as Ï‰â€‹(1/SNR2)ğœ”1superscriptSNR2\omega(1/\operatorname{SNR}^{2}). This rate is achieved by a simple spectral algorithm. We propose two additional algorithms based on non-convex optimization and expectation-maximization. We also draw a connection between the multireference alignment problem and the spiked covariance model.

Index Terms:
multireference alignment, spectral algorithm, method of moments, spiked covariance model, non-convex optimization, expectation-maximization, cryoâ€“EM

I Introduction

The problem of multireference alignment (MRA) arises in a variety of engineering and scientific applications, among them structural biologyÂ [1, 2, 3, 4, 5], radarÂ [6, 7], roboticsÂ [8] and image processingÂ [9, 10, 11]. In these applications, one aims to estimate a signal from its translated or rotated noisy copies. The problem also serves as a simplified model for more general problems like single-particle reconstruction by cryoâ€“electron microscopy (cryoâ€“EM), in which a three-dimensional density is recovered from two-dimensional projections taken at unknown viewing directionsÂ [12, 13, 14].

In this paper, we focus on the one-dimensional discrete MRA problem on a circle. In this model, we acquire Nğ‘N measurements from the model

Yj=RSjâ€‹x+Ïƒâ€‹Gj,j=1,â€¦,N,formulae-sequencesubscriptğ‘Œğ‘—subscriptğ‘…subscriptğ‘†ğ‘—ğ‘¥ğœsubscriptğºğ‘—ğ‘—1â€¦ğ‘Y_{j}=R_{S_{j}}x+\sigma G_{j},\quad j=1,\dots,N, (I.1)

where the Gjsubscriptğºğ‘—G_{j} are i.i.d and drawn from ğ’©â€‹(0,IL)ğ’©0subscriptğ¼ğ¿{\mathcal{N}}(0,I_{L}), i.e. Gjâˆˆâ„Lsubscriptğºğ‘—superscriptâ„ğ¿G_{j}\in\mathbb{R}^{L} and its entries are i.i.d standard Gaussian variables. The operator Rssubscriptğ‘…ğ‘ R_{s} translates a signal xâˆˆâ„Lğ‘¥superscriptâ„ğ¿x\in\mathbb{R}^{L} circularly by sğ‘ s elements, namely, (Rsâ€‹x)â€‹[i]=xâ€‹[iâˆ’s]subscriptğ‘…ğ‘ ğ‘¥delimited-[]ğ‘–ğ‘¥delimited-[]ğ‘–ğ‘ (R_{s}x)[i]=x[i-s], where all indices should be considered as modulo Lğ¿L. The translations Sjsubscriptğ‘†ğ‘—S_{j} are i.i.d. and drawn from some unknown distribution ÏğœŒ\rho on â„¤Lsubscriptâ„¤ğ¿{\mathbb{Z}}_{L}. FigureÂ I.1 illustrates the MRA problem in different noise levels.

Previous approaches for estimating xğ‘¥x fromÂ (I.1) can be broadly classified into two main categories. The first approach is based on estimating the translations Sjsubscriptğ‘†ğ‘—S_{j}, aligning all observations, and averaging them to suppress the noise. However, alignment is too erroneous in low signalâ€“toâ€“noise ratio (SNRSNR\operatorname{SNR})Â [15, 16], defined here as SNR:=âˆ¥xâˆ¥2/Ïƒ2\operatorname{SNR}\mathrel{\mathop{\mathchar 58\relax}}=\|x\|^{2}/\sigma^{2}. Note that while the translations Sjsubscriptğ‘†ğ‘—S_{j} are unknown, their estimation is not the primary goal of the problem. The translations are referred to as nuisance variables.

An alternative approach aims at estimating the signal xğ‘¥x directly. Existing methods bypass the need to estimate the translations by employing expectation-maximization (EM) methods or by using features that are invariant under translationÂ [17]. SectionÂ II is devoted to a detailed discussion on existing results and algorithms for MRA. In this paper, we take a different route by trying to estimate both the signal and the distribution of translations ÏğœŒ\rho simultaneously. When ÏğœŒ\rho is aperiodic, it turns out this is an easier problem than ignoring the fact that ÏğœŒ\rho is not uniform and estimating xğ‘¥x alone.

In this paper we focus on the regime where both the number of observations and the variance of the noise are diverging. More specifically, our goal is to determine the sample complexity of (I.1), which we define to be the minimal number of measurements, as a function of the SNR, required such that there is a sequence of estimators {X^N}subscript^ğ‘‹ğ‘\{\hat{X}_{N}\} of xğ‘¥x with mean square error (MSE) converging to 00 as Nğ‘N diverges. We define the MSE as

MSE=1â€–xâ€–22â€‹ğ”¼â€‹[minsâˆˆâ„¤Lâ¡â€–Rsâ€‹X^âˆ’xâ€–22],MSE1superscriptsubscriptnormğ‘¥22ğ”¼delimited-[]subscriptğ‘ subscriptâ„¤ğ¿subscriptsuperscriptnormsubscriptğ‘…ğ‘ ^ğ‘‹ğ‘¥22\mathrm{MSE}=\frac{1}{\|x\|_{2}^{2}}\mathbb{E}\left[\min_{s\in\mathbb{Z}_{L}}\|R_{s}\widehat{X}-x\|^{2}_{2}\right], (I.2)

where the expectation is taken over the estimator X^^ğ‘‹\widehat{X}, which is a function of the random observations Yjsubscriptğ‘Œğ‘—Y_{j} with distribution determined by (I.1). Allowing for a cyclic shift in (I.2) is intrinsic to the problem: if we apply a shift Rssubscriptğ‘…ğ‘ R_{s} to xğ‘¥x, and its inverse Râˆ’ssubscriptğ‘…ğ‘ R_{-s} to the right of ÏğœŒ\rho, we will produce exactly the same samples, thus there is no estimator X^^ğ‘‹\hat{X} that is able to distinguish the observations that originate from xğ‘¥x and the ones from Rsâ€‹xsubscriptğ‘…ğ‘ ğ‘¥R_{s}x.

InÂ [18], it was proven that when ÏğœŒ\rho is the uniform distribution, then in the low SNR regime, the sample complexity for estimating signals with non-vanishing discrete Fourier transform (DFT) is Ï‰â€‹(1/SNR3)ğœ”1superscriptSNR3\omega(1/\operatorname{SNR}^{3}). In this work, we show that if the translation distribution ÏğœŒ\rho is aperiodic, meaning there is no 1â‰¤â„“â‰¤Lâˆ’11â„“ğ¿11\leq\ell\leq L-1 where Ïâ€‹[k+â„“]=Ïâ€‹[k]ğœŒdelimited-[]ğ‘˜â„“ğœŒdelimited-[]ğ‘˜\rho[k+\ell]=\rho[k] for all 0â‰¤kâ‰¤Lâˆ’10ğ‘˜ğ¿10\leq k\leq L-1, the sample complexity for estimating these signals is Ï‰â€‹(1/SNR2)ğœ”1superscriptSNR2\omega(1/\operatorname{SNR}^{2}). This rate is optimal and can be provably achieved by a spectral algorithm based on the first two moments of the data. The main result of this paper is stated as follows:

Main Result (informal): Consider the modelÂ (I.1) and suppose that xâˆˆâ„Lğ‘¥superscriptâ„ğ¿x\in\mathbb{R}^{L} has a non-vanishing DFTDFT\operatorname{DFT}. When ÏğœŒ\rho is aperiodic, the sample complexity of the MRA problem is Ï‰â€‹(1/SNR2)ğœ”1superscriptSNR2\omega(1/\operatorname{SNR}^{2}). This sample complexity is achieved by a spectral algorithm, detailed in Algorithms 1 and 2, based on the first two moments of the data. Conversely, the sample complexity for any periodic distribution, in particular the uniform distribution, scales like Ï‰â€‹(1/SNR3)ğœ”1superscriptSNR3\omega(1/\operatorname{SNR}^{3}).

The proposed framework is based on a reliable estimation of the first two moments of the data. Hence, it requires only one pass over the measurements, low storage resources and is computationally efficient. To estimate the signal from the estimated moments, we propose, in addition to the aforementioned spectral algorithm, a non-convex least-squares (LS) algorithm. While the problem is non-convex, it empirically converges to the underlying signal, in the absence of noise, from a random initialization. As an alternative to the method of moments, we also examine an expectation-maximization (EM) algorithm.

The outline of the paper is as follows. SectionÂ II provides a detailed discussion of existing results and algorithms for MRA. In SectionÂ III we prove that the sample complexity is lower bounded by Ï‰â€‹(1/SNR2)ğœ”1superscriptSNR2\omega(1/\operatorname{SNR}^{2}). We also show that the sample complexity of any periodic distribution of translations with a period of less than L/2ğ¿2L/2 scales as Ï‰â€‹(1/SNR3)ğœ”1superscriptSNR3\omega(1/\operatorname{SNR}^{3}). This is an extension of the results ofÂ [18], which considered the uniform distribution case. In SectionÂ IV we show that if the distribution is aperiodic, or is periodic with period L/2ğ¿2L/2, then any signal with non-vanishing DFTDFT\operatorname{DFT} can be estimated from its first and second moments, achieving the optimal estimation rate. SectionÂ V draws the connections between the MRA model and the well-studied spiked covariance modelÂ [19, 20, 21, 22, 23]. SectionÂ VI discusses and analyzes alternative algorithmic methods based on LS and EM. SectionÂ VII examines the performance of the proposed algorithms by numerical simulations. SectionÂ VIII concludes the paper and proposes potential future extensions.

II Related work

II-A Multireference alignment via synchronization

Given the translations sjsubscriptğ‘ ğ‘—s_{j}, the MRA problemÂ (I.1) is easy. One trivial unbiased estimator of xğ‘¥x is given by aligning all measurements and then averaging to suppress the noise, namely,

X^=1Nâ€‹âˆ‘j=1NRsjâˆ’1â€‹Yj.^ğ‘‹1ğ‘superscriptsubscriptğ‘—1ğ‘superscriptsubscriptğ‘…subscriptğ‘ ğ‘—1subscriptğ‘Œğ‘—\widehat{X}=\frac{1}{N}\sum_{j=1}^{N}R_{s_{j}}^{-1}Y_{j}. (II.1)

The variance of this estimator is Ïƒ2/Nsuperscriptğœ2ğ‘\sigma^{2}/N and therefore the number of measurements Nğ‘N needs to scale like Ïƒ2superscriptğœ2\sigma^{2} to retain a constant estimation error. In other words, the sample complexity grows like Ï‰â€‹(1/SNR)ğœ”1SNR\omega(1/\operatorname{SNR}). One can replaceÂ (II.1) with other estimators, such as James-Stein shrinkageÂ [24, 25, 26], which might improve the numerical performance with finite number of samples, but would not change the asymptotic sample complexity. In practice, we do not have access to the underlying translations. However, if one can obtain a reliable estimation of the unknown translations s^jsubscript^ğ‘ ğ‘—{\hat{s}_{j}}, then one can estimate xğ‘¥x by the sample mean as inÂ (II.1) at sample complexity Ï‰â€‹(1/SNR)ğœ”1SNR\omega(1/\operatorname{SNR}). This motivates the design of synchronization methods that aim to estimate the translations sjsubscriptğ‘ ğ‘—s_{j} from the data yjsubscriptğ‘¦ğ‘—y_{j}.

A naÃ¯ve approach for synchronization could be to fix one observation as a template, say Y1subscriptğ‘Œ1Y_{1}, and estimate the relative translation of each Yjsubscriptğ‘Œğ‘—Y_{j}, with respect to Y1subscriptğ‘Œ1Y_{1}, by the peak of their cross-correlation:

S^j=argâ¡maxsâ€‹âˆ‘i=0Lâˆ’1Y1â€‹[i]â€‹Yjâ€‹[i+s].subscript^ğ‘†ğ‘—subscriptğ‘ superscriptsubscriptğ‘–0ğ¿1subscriptğ‘Œ1delimited-[]ğ‘–subscriptğ‘Œğ‘—delimited-[]ğ‘–ğ‘ \hat{S}_{j}=\arg\max_{s}\sum_{i=0}^{L-1}Y_{1}[i]Y_{j}[i+s].

This approach may work in the high SNRSNR\operatorname{SNR} regimes, but fails as the noise level increases (see for instance Figure I.1 inÂ [17]). Many alternative synchronization methods were proposed in the literature. For instance, the angular synchronization method aims at aligning all pairwise observations simultaneouslyÂ [27, 28, 29, 30, 31, 32]. Other methods propose to align through different semidefinite programs (SDPs)Â [33, 34, 35, 36]. However, alignment is impossible at the low SNR regime, no matter how many measurements are acquired [16]. For instance, for the continuous counterpart ofÂ (I.1), it has been shown that the CrÃ¡merâ€“Rao lower bound is proportional to Ïƒ2superscriptğœ2\sigma^{2} and does not depend on Nğ‘N. This bound holds even if the sought signal is knownÂ [15].

II-B Multireference alignment in low SNR

This section reviews recent works on MRA in the low SNR regime, in which methods based on alignment fail. The key idea is to estimate the signal directly, without estimating the translations beforehand. As will be emphasized throughout, previous works did not consider the translation distribution ÏğœŒ\rho, and either assumed or enforced it to be uniform.

InÂ [18], it was shown that if the translations are uniformly distributed, namely, Sâˆ¼Uniformâ€‹[0,1,â€¦,Lâˆ’1]similar-toğ‘†Uniform01â€¦ğ¿1S\sim\text{Uniform}[0,1,\dots,L-1], then the number of measurements needs to scale like Ï‰â€‹(1/SNR3)ğœ”1superscriptSNR3\omega(1/\operatorname{SNR}^{3}) for the estimator to converge in L2superscriptğ¿2L^{2} to the true signal. A follow-up paperÂ [37] showed that this rate can be achieved by a tensor decomposition algorithm. The analysis of the uniform distribution is of particular interest since, no matter what ÏğœŒ\rho is, one can always enforce it to be uniform. This can be done simply by reshuffling all measurements by zj=RSjâ€²â€‹yjsubscriptğ‘§ğ‘—subscriptğ‘…subscriptsuperscriptğ‘†â€²ğ‘—subscriptğ‘¦ğ‘—z_{j}=R_{S^{\prime}_{j}}y_{j}, where Sjâ€²subscriptsuperscriptğ‘†â€²ğ‘—S^{\prime}_{j} are drawn from the uniform distribution. The new set of measurements zjsubscriptğ‘§ğ‘—z_{j} obeys the MRA modelÂ (I.1) with uniform translation distribution. However, as will be shown, this is in general a bad strategy, since the uniform distribution has a sample complexity scaling as Ï‰â€‹(1/SNR3)ğœ”1superscriptSNR3\omega(1/\operatorname{SNR}^{3}).

From the algorithmic pointâ€“ofâ€“view, a recent paperÂ [17] proposes a method that completely overcomes the need to estimate the translations. The core idea is to estimate features of the underlying signal that are invariant under cyclic translation. Particularly, it was proposed to estimate the mean, power spectrum and bispectrum of the signal from the moments of the data. Since these invariant features are polynomials in the signal with degree at most three, they can be estimated at sample complexity growing like Ï‰â€‹(1/SNR3)ğœ”1superscriptSNR3\omega(1/\operatorname{SNR}^{3}). Using these invariant features, one can recover the signal as Nâ†’âˆâ†’ğ‘N\to\infty using a variety of algorithmsÂ [17]. InÂ [38], it was shown that a similar technique can be used to estimate several signals simultaneously from heterogeneous samples (see alsoÂ [37, SectionÂ 5]). Since the invariant feature technique requires only one pass over the data, it can be performed in a streaming mode, can be parallelized, requires low storage resources of ğ’ªâ€‹(L2)ğ’ªsuperscriptğ¿2\mathcal{O}(L^{2}), and has low computational load. The framework proposed in this paper is also based on estimating moments of the data and therefore enjoys the same advantages; however, since we only require second-order moments, we bring the sample complexity down to Ï‰â€‹(1/SNR2)ğœ”1superscriptSNR2\omega(1/\operatorname{SNR}^{2}).

Another approach for MRA is to apply an EM algorithmÂ [39]. EM is an iterative algorithm that aims to find the marginalized maximum likelihood estimator and is used ubiquitously in many statistical models. For the MRA modelÂ (I.1), and under the assumption that the translations are drawn from the uniform distribution, this algorithm takes a simple form and consists of two steps at each iterationÂ [17]. Given a current estimation xkâˆ’1subscriptğ‘¥ğ‘˜1x_{k-1}, the first step (called the E-step) computes a set of weights which can be understood as the translation distribution of each measurement yjsubscriptğ‘¦ğ‘—y_{j}, if xkâˆ’1subscriptğ‘¥ğ‘˜1x_{k-1} was the underlying signal. These weights are computed by

wkâ„“,j=Ckjâ€‹eâˆ’12â€‹Ïƒ2â€‹â€–Râ„“â€‹xkâˆ’1âˆ’yjâ€–22,superscriptsubscriptğ‘¤ğ‘˜â„“ğ‘—superscriptsubscriptğ¶ğ‘˜ğ‘—superscriptğ‘’12superscriptğœ2superscriptsubscriptnormsubscriptğ‘…â„“subscriptğ‘¥ğ‘˜1subscriptğ‘¦ğ‘—22w_{k}^{\ell,j}=C_{k}^{j}e^{-\frac{1}{2\sigma^{2}}\|R_{\ell}x_{k-1}-y_{j}\|_{2}^{2}},

where Ckjsuperscriptsubscriptğ¶ğ‘˜ğ‘—C_{k}^{j} is a normalization factor so that âˆ‘â„“wkâ„“,j=1subscriptâ„“superscriptsubscriptğ‘¤ğ‘˜â„“ğ‘—1\sum_{\ell}w_{k}^{\ell,j}=1. Then, the signal estimation is updated by marginalizing over the distributions and averaging (called the M-step):

xk=1Nâ€‹âˆ‘j=1Nâˆ‘â„“=0Lâˆ’1wkâ„“,jâ€‹Râ„“âˆ’1â€‹yj.subscriptğ‘¥ğ‘˜1ğ‘superscriptsubscriptğ‘—1ğ‘superscriptsubscriptâ„“0ğ¿1superscriptsubscriptğ‘¤ğ‘˜â„“ğ‘—superscriptsubscriptğ‘…â„“1subscriptğ‘¦ğ‘—x_{k}=\frac{1}{N}\sum_{j=1}^{N}\sum_{\ell=0}^{L-1}w_{k}^{\ell,j}R_{\ell}^{-1}y_{j}. (II.2)

The EM algorithm enjoys an excellent numerical performance; however, its computational load and storage requirements are heavy since it passes through all the data at each iteration. In SectionÂ VI-B, we modify the standard EM algorithm to take the distribution into account.

III Information theoretic lower bound

In this section, we provide lower bounds for the MSE of an estimator of the signal in terms of the SNRSNR\operatorname{SNR} and the number of observations Nğ‘N. In particular, we show that under mild conditions on the signal the MSE is bounded away from zero if N=Î©â€‹(1/SNR2)ğ‘Î©1superscriptSNR2N=\Omega(1/\operatorname{SNR}^{2}). As described in SectionÂ IV, the MSEMSE\mathrm{MSE} of AlgorithmÂ 2 converges to 00 if the number of measurements grows like Ï‰â€‹(1/SNR2)ğœ”1superscriptSNR2\omega(1/\operatorname{SNR}^{2}). In addition, if the distribution is periodic, the MSE is bounded away from zero if N=Oâ€‹(1/SNR3)ğ‘ğ‘‚1superscriptSNR3N={O}(1/\operatorname{SNR}^{3}). The framework proposed inÂ [17] and described in SectionÂ II achieves this sample complexity for any distribution.

Recall that we can estimate the signal only up to cyclic translation. We define the best alignment of X^^ğ‘‹\widehat{X} with xğ‘¥x by

Ï•xâ€‹(X^)=argminzâˆˆ{Rsâ€‹X^}sâˆˆâ„¤Lâ€–zâˆ’xâ€–.subscriptitalic-Ï•ğ‘¥^ğ‘‹subscriptargminğ‘§subscriptsubscriptğ‘…ğ‘ ^ğ‘‹ğ‘ subscriptâ„¤ğ¿normğ‘§ğ‘¥\phi_{x}(\widehat{X})=\operatorname*{argmin}_{z\in\{R_{s}\widehat{X}\}_{s\in{\mathbb{Z}}_{L}}}\|z-x\|. (III.1)

Accordingly, we write (I.2) as

MSE =1â€–xâ€–2â€‹ğ”¼â€‹[â€–Ï•xâ€‹(X^)âˆ’xâ€–22].absent1superscriptnormğ‘¥2ğ”¼delimited-[]subscriptsuperscriptnormsubscriptitalic-Ï•ğ‘¥^ğ‘‹ğ‘¥22\displaystyle=\frac{1}{\|x\|^{2}}\mathbb{E}\left[\|\phi_{x}(\widehat{X})-x\|^{2}_{2}\right]. (III.2)

Since we are interested in estimators that converge to a cyclic shift of xğ‘¥x in L2superscriptğ¿2L^{2} as Nğ‘N diverges, we only consider estimators which are consistent, i.e., Ï•xâ€‹(X^)â†’xâ†’subscriptitalic-Ï•ğ‘¥^ğ‘‹ğ‘¥\phi_{x}(\widehat{X})\rightarrow x as Nâ†’âˆâ†’ğ‘N\to\infty. However the information lower bounds presented in this paper can be adapted to biased estimators (see TheoremÂ III.5). We now present the main results of this section as follows:

Theorem III.1.

Assume that xğ‘¥x is not a constant vector. If X^^ğ‘‹\widehat{X} is a consistent estimator of xğ‘¥x, then

MSEâ‰¥18â€‹Nâ€‹1SNR2âˆ’Oâ€‹(1Nâ€‹SNR1.5).MSE18ğ‘1superscriptSNR2ğ‘‚1ğ‘superscriptSNR1.5\mathrm{MSE}\geq\frac{1}{8N}\frac{1}{\operatorname{SNR}^{2}}-{O}\left(\frac{1}{N\operatorname{SNR}^{1.5}}\right). (III.3)

Moreover, if ÏğœŒ\rho is periodic, with a period â„“<L2â„“ğ¿2\ell<\frac{L}{2}, then

MSEâ‰¥154â€‹Nâ€‹Lâˆ’2â€‹â„“2â€‹â„“â€‹1SNR3âˆ’Oâ€‹(1Nâ€‹SNR2.5).MSE154ğ‘ğ¿2â„“2â„“1superscriptSNR3ğ‘‚1ğ‘superscriptSNR2.5\mathrm{MSE}\geq\frac{1}{54N}\frac{L-2\ell}{2\ell}\frac{1}{\operatorname{SNR}^{3}}-{O}\left(\frac{1}{N\operatorname{SNR}^{2.5}}\right). (III.4)

Equation (III.3) implies that if the number of measurements Nğ‘N is Oâ€‹(1/SNR2)ğ‘‚1superscriptSNR2{O}(1/\operatorname{SNR}^{2}) and ÏğœŒ\rho is aperiodic, the MSE is bounded away from 00, thus the sample complexity is lower bounded by Ï‰â€‹(1/SNR2)ğœ”1superscriptSNR2\omega(1/\operatorname{SNR}^{2}). Similarly, when ÏğœŒ\rho is periodic with a period â„“<L2â„“ğ¿2\ell<\frac{L}{2}, (III.4) implies that the sample complexity is lower bounded by Ï‰â€‹(1/SNR3)ğœ”1superscriptSNR3\omega(1/\operatorname{SNR}^{3}).

Note that previous workÂ [18] derived the sample complexity for the uniform distribution of translations. TheoremÂ III.1 extends it to any distribution. In addition, we extendÂ [18] by providing the constant that multiplies 1/Sâ€‹Nâ€‹R31ğ‘†ğ‘superscriptğ‘…31/SNR^{3}, for the uniform distribution case.

In the rest of this section, we develop the main tools required to prove TheoremÂ III.1. Specifically, we start by introducing an auxiliary notation and definitions. Then, in SectionÂ III-B, we use an adaptation of the Chapman-Robbins lower boundÂ [40], which is a generalization of the CramÃ©r-Rao boundÂ [41], to derive a lower bound on the MSE in terms of the Ï‡2superscriptğœ’2\chi^{2} divergence. Then, in SectionÂ III-C, we express the Ï‡2superscriptğœ’2\chi^{2} divergence in terms of the Taylor expansion of the posterior probability density and the moment tensors . Finally in section III-D we combine the results from SectionÂ III-B and SectionÂ III-C to obtain a general lower bound for MRA, which we apply for the case when ÏğœŒ\rho is aperiodic and periodic, respectively. The final details of the proof of TheoremÂ III.1 are given in AppendixÂ -E.

Thus, to prove Theorem III.1, we use intermediate results which explore the limit (x~,Ï~)â†’(x,Ï)â†’~ğ‘¥~ğœŒğ‘¥ğœŒ(\tilde{x},\tilde{\rho})\rightarrow(x,\rho), and thus provide tighter bounds. As a final remark on the results in this section, Theorem III.7 is not particular to MRA and can be easily generalized to a broader class of problems, which consider the actions of different groups and include the problem of single-particle reconstruction using cryo-EM [42]. A recent paper [18] obtains similar results for minimax lower bounds, and employs techniques from computational algebra to estimate dÂ¯Â¯ğ‘‘\bar{d}, and consequently the sample complexity, for a variety of models, such as cryo-EM and heterogeneous MRA.

IV Provable algorithm based on the first two moments

In this section, we provide a spectral algorithm to estimate the signal, up to cyclic translation, from the first and second moments of the data, provided that the translation distribution is aperiodic. We prove that this algorithm estimates the signal exactly with high probability in the limit of SNR tending to 00 with a growing number of samples; we will describe the asymptotic model more precisely in Section IV-C. Because the method relies on only second-order information, its sample complexity in this case only grows like Ï‰â€‹(1/SNR2)ğœ”1superscriptSNR2\omega(1/\operatorname{SNR}^{2}), compared to sample complexity growing as Ï‰â€‹(1/SNR3)ğœ”1superscriptSNR3\omega(1/\operatorname{SNR}^{3}) if the translation distribution is periodic (with period smaller than L/2ğ¿2L/2; see SectionÂ IV-D). As we proved in SectionÂ III, Ï‰â€‹(1/SNR2)ğœ”1superscriptSNR2\omega(1/\operatorname{SNR}^{2}) is indeed the sample complexity for aperiodic distributions.

IV-A Moments of RSâ€‹xsubscriptğ‘…ğ‘†ğ‘¥R_{S}x

Before describing the algorithm, we will review a few basic properties of the moments of the random vectors RSâ€‹xsubscriptğ‘…ğ‘†ğ‘¥R_{S}x, defined in Definition III.2, and conclude with a theoretical result about the sufficient information they hold.

IV-C Estimating xğ‘¥x in low SNR

Section IV-B shows that Algorithm 1 recovers xğ‘¥x exactly from the exact values of M1superscriptğ‘€1M^{1} and M2superscriptğ‘€2M^{2}, as long as the DFT of xğ‘¥x is non-vanishing and ÏğœŒ\rho has at least one distinct entry. In this section we show that under the same conditions, Algorithm 1 is stable under small perturbations of the moments. We also show that if N=Ï‰â€‹(Ïƒ4)ğ‘ğœ”superscriptğœ4N=\omega(\sigma^{4}), or equivalently N=Ï‰â€‹(1/SNR2)ğ‘ğœ”1superscriptSNR2N=\omega(1/\operatorname{SNR}^{2}), the MSE of the estimate given by Algorithm 1 converges to 00 as Nğ‘N diverges.

We first observe that whenever ÏğœŒ\rho is aperiodic, we can modify the observations to assume that ÏğœŒ\rho in fact has all distinct entries. Indeed, we generate a new set of measurements zj=RSjâ€²â€‹yjsubscriptğ‘§ğ‘—subscriptğ‘…subscriptsuperscriptğ‘†â€²ğ‘—subscriptğ‘¦ğ‘—z_{j}=R_{S^{\prime}_{j}}y_{j}, where Sjâ€²subscriptsuperscriptğ‘†â€²ğ‘—S^{\prime}_{j} are drawn from a new, known distribution Î¸ğœƒ\theta. In this case, the translations are distributed according to Ïâˆ—Î¸âˆ—ğœŒğœƒ\rho\ast\theta. The following lemma shows that by choosing Î¸ğœƒ\theta as a random probability distribution on the simplex, we can ensure that all entries of Ïâˆ—Î¸âˆ—ğœŒğœƒ\rho\ast\theta are distinct with probability 111. Note that if the DFT of Î¸ğœƒ\theta is non-vanishing (which holds with probability 1 for random Î¸ğœƒ\theta), then one can recover fully ÏğœŒ\rho from Ïâˆ—Î¸âˆ—ğœŒğœƒ\rho\ast\theta.

Lemma IV.3.

Let ÏğœŒ\rho be an aperiodic vector on the simplex and let Î¸ğœƒ\theta be a random probability density function on the simplex. Then, all entries of Ïâˆ—Î¸âˆ—ğœŒğœƒ\rho\ast\theta are distinct with probability 1.

Proof.

See AppendixÂ -G. âˆ

Using this lemma, we will assume from now on that all entries of ÏğœŒ\rho are distinct. The following corollary states that Algorithm 1 is stable to perturbations of the moments and power spectrum:

Corollary IV.4.

Suppose xğ‘¥x has non-vanishing DFTDFT\operatorname{DFT} and denote by M^1superscript^ğ‘€1\widehat{M}\phantom{M}^{1} and M^2superscript^ğ‘€2\widehat{M}\phantom{M}^{2} the sample moments defined by equations (IV.3) and (IV.5). See AppendixÂ -H. âˆ

The following theorem shows that if Nğ‘N grows like Ï‰â€‹(Ïƒ4)ğœ”superscriptğœ4\omega(\sigma^{4}), the MSE of the estimator converges to 00 as Nğ‘N diverges.

IV-D Non-uniqueness for periodic ÏğœŒ\rho

We have shown that the first and the second moments suffice to determine the signal if the distribution is aperiodic. In this section, we provide a complementary result, showing that if the distribution is periodic, then having the first two moments is not enough to uniquely determine a signal with non-vanishing DFTDFT\operatorname{DFT}. In particular, given a distribution ÏğœŒ\rho with period â„“â„“\ell, a signal x2subscriptğ‘¥2x_{2} has the same first two moments as x1subscriptğ‘¥1x_{1} if it satisfies:

(Fâ€‹x2)â€‹[k]={(Fâ€‹x1)â€‹[k],k=tâ€‹Lâ„“,t=0,â€¦,â„“âˆ’1,âˆ’(Fâ€‹x1)â€‹[k],Â otherwise.Â ğ¹subscriptğ‘¥2delimited-[]ğ‘˜casesğ¹subscriptğ‘¥1delimited-[]ğ‘˜formulae-sequenceğ‘˜ğ‘¡ğ¿â„“ğ‘¡0â€¦â„“1ğ¹subscriptğ‘¥1delimited-[]ğ‘˜Â otherwise.Â (F{x_{2}})[k]=\left\{\begin{array}[]{ll}(F{x_{1}})[k],&k=t\frac{L}{\ell},\quad t=0,\ldots,\ell-1,\\ -(F{x_{1}})[k],&\mbox{ otherwise. }\end{array}\right. (IV.9)

This construction is demonstrated in FigureÂ IV.1.

Proposition IV.6.

Let â„“<L/2â„“ğ¿2\ell<L/2 be a divisor of L>1ğ¿1L>1. Suppose that ÏğœŒ\rho is periodic, with period â„“â„“\ell, and let x1subscriptğ‘¥1x_{1} be a given signal with non-vanishing DFTDFT\operatorname{DFT}. Then the signal x2subscriptğ‘¥2x_{2} defined by (IV.9) is not a translation of x1subscriptğ‘¥1x_{1}, and has the same first and second moments as x1subscriptğ‘¥1x_{1}. Therefore, if the distribution is periodic, then any signal with non-vanishing DFTDFT\operatorname{DFT} is not uniquely determined from its first two moments.

Proof.

See AppendixÂ -J. âˆ

In SectionÂ III we established this result from an information-theoretic perspective by showing that the sample complexity for periodic distribution grows like Ï‰â€‹(1/SNR3)ğœ”1superscriptSNR3\omega(1/\operatorname{SNR}^{3}), and extendingÂ [18] that considered only the uniform distribution. Indeed, the uniform distribution is merely a special case of periodic distributions with minimal period â„“=1â„“1\ell=1. When â„“>1â„“1\ell>1, one can interpret the periodicity as having a uniform distribution over the different cosets of â„¤Lsubscriptâ„¤ğ¿\mathbb{Z}_{L} with respect to the subgroup generated by a translation in â„“â„“\ell coordinates. These cosets are exactly the analogue of the sparsity pattern of Fâ€‹Ïğ¹ğœŒ{F{\rho}} attained by jumps of L/â„“ğ¿â„“L/\ell. This also explains why uniformity is the only pathological case for a prime Lğ¿L. Therefore, if one can choose how to sample the signal, a prime number of samples should be considered.

As it turns out, there is one special case where the first two moments are enough to determine xğ‘¥x uniquely, up to cyclic translation, even when ÏğœŒ\rho is periodic. This special case occurs when Lğ¿L is even and ÏğœŒ\rho is L/2ğ¿2L/2-periodic. Note that in this case the information theoretic lower bound presented in section III is also Ï‰â€‹(1/SNR2)ğœ”1superscriptSNR2\omega(1/\operatorname{SNR}^{2}). This result is formulated in the following claim:

Claim IV.7.

Suppose that xğ‘¥x has non-vanishing DFTDFT\operatorname{DFT}, Lğ¿L is even and ÏğœŒ\rho is L/2ğ¿2L/2-periodic. Then, xğ‘¥x is uniquely determined from its first two moments, up to global translation.

Proof.

See AppendixÂ -K. âˆ

V Connection with the spiked covariance model

In this section, we point out a connection between the spectral algorithm presented in SectionÂ IV, and the spiked covariance model well-known in statisticsÂ [19, 20, 21, 22, 23]. Though somewhat informal, this analysis will provide insight into how the complexity of recovering xğ‘¥x depends on the dimension Lğ¿L when the distribution ÏğœŒ\rho has a fixed support size.

In the spiked model, we observe a matrix

ğ˜=ğ—+ğ†âˆˆâ„LÃ—N,ğ˜ğ—ğ†superscriptâ„ğ¿ğ‘\displaystyle\mathbf{Y}=\mathbf{X}+\mathbf{G}\in\mathbb{R}^{L\times N}, (V.1)

where ğ—ğ—\mathbf{X} is a rank rğ‘Ÿr matrix and

ğ†=(Giâ€‹j),Giâ€‹jâ€‹âˆ¼iâ€‹iâ€‹dâ€‹ğ’©â€‹(0,Ïƒ2).ğ†subscriptğºğ‘–ğ‘—subscriptğºğ‘–ğ‘—ğ‘–ğ‘–ğ‘‘similar-toğ’©0superscriptğœ2\mathbf{G}=(G_{ij}),\quad G_{ij}\overset{iid}{\sim}\mathcal{N}(0,\sigma^{2}).

This model is typically studied in the high-dimensional regime, in which Lğ¿L grows proportionally to Nğ‘N; that is, L=Lâ€‹(N)ğ¿ğ¿ğ‘L=L(N) and L/Nâ†’Î³>0â†’ğ¿ğ‘ğ›¾0L/N\to\gamma>0 as Nâ†’âˆâ†’ğ‘N\to\infty. In this setting, there is a precise understanding of the limiting behavior of the data matrix ğ˜ğ˜\mathbf{Y} and the low-rank matrix ğ—=[X1,â€¦,XN]ğ—subscriptğ‘‹1â€¦subscriptğ‘‹ğ‘\mathbf{X}=[X_{1},\dots,X_{N}].

In [22] (see also [20]), it is shown that when the low-rank matrix ğ—ğ—\mathbf{X} is random (for instance, its columns may be drawn from a suitable low-rank, mean-zero distribution), then the limiting cosine cğ‘c of the angles between the top eigenvector of ğ—ğ—Tsuperscriptğ—ğ—ğ‘‡\mathbf{X}\mathbf{X}^{T} and the top eigenvector of ğ˜ğ˜Tsuperscriptğ˜ğ˜ğ‘‡\mathbf{Y}\mathbf{Y}^{T} is given by the formula:

c2={1âˆ’Ïƒ4â€‹Î³/Î»21+Ïƒ2â€‹Î³/Î»Â ifÂ â€‹Î»>Ïƒ2â€‹Î³,0Â otherwise,superscriptğ‘2cases1superscriptğœ4ğ›¾superscriptğœ†21superscriptğœ2ğ›¾ğœ†Â ifÂ ğœ†superscriptğœ2ğ›¾0Â otherwise,\displaystyle c^{2}=\begin{cases}\frac{1-\sigma^{4}\gamma/\lambda^{2}}{1+\sigma^{2}\gamma/\lambda}&\text{ if }\lambda>\sigma^{2}\sqrt{\gamma},\\ 0&\text{ otherwise,}\end{cases} (V.2)

where Î»ğœ†\lambda is the top eigenvalue of ğ—ğ—T/Nsuperscriptğ—ğ—ğ‘‡ğ‘\mathbf{X}\mathbf{X}^{T}/N.

The key phenomenon is the phase transition at

Î»câ€‹râ€‹iâ€‹tâ€‹iâ€‹câ€‹aâ€‹l=Ïƒ2â€‹Î³.subscriptğœ†ğ‘ğ‘Ÿğ‘–ğ‘¡ğ‘–ğ‘ğ‘ğ‘™superscriptğœ2ğ›¾\lambda_{critical}=\sigma^{2}\sqrt{\gamma}. (V.3)

It is only when Î»ğœ†\lambda is greater than this critical value that we are guaranteed a non-trivial correlation between the top eigenvector of the observed matrix ğ˜ğ˜T/Nsuperscriptğ˜ğ˜ğ‘‡ğ‘\mathbf{Y}\mathbf{Y}^{T}/N and the top eigenvector of ğ—ğ—T/Nsuperscriptğ—ğ—ğ‘‡ğ‘\mathbf{X}\mathbf{X}^{T}/N.

We can view the observation model in the one-dimensional MRA modelÂ (I.1) as a special instance of the spiked model, by taking the iğ‘–ith column of ğ—ğ—\mathbf{X} to be Xi=RSiâ€‹xsubscriptğ‘‹ğ‘–subscriptğ‘…subscriptğ‘†ğ‘–ğ‘¥X_{i}=R_{S_{i}}x. As Nâ†’âˆâ†’ğ‘N\to\infty, we can write

Consequently, under the assumption that the DFTDFT\operatorname{DFT} of xğ‘¥x does not vanish, the rank of ğ—ğ—\mathbf{X} is the size of the support of ÏğœŒ{\rho}. When the support size of ÏğœŒ\rho is fixed at rğ‘Ÿr, the MRA problem is an instance of the spiked model.

Let us assume that the |(Fâ€‹x)â€‹[k]|=1ğ¹ğ‘¥delimited-[]ğ‘˜1|(Fx)[k]|=1 for all kğ‘˜k. This can be done by estimating the power spectrum first and then normalizing all Fourier coefficients. In this case, Cxsubscriptğ¶ğ‘¥C_{x} is an orthogonal matrix. In other words, xâŸ‚Râ„“â€‹xperpendicular-toğ‘¥subscriptğ‘…â„“ğ‘¥x\perp R_{\ell}x for every â„“â‰ 0â„“0\ell\neq 0; consequently, the Râ„“â€‹xsubscriptğ‘…â„“ğ‘¥R_{\ell}x are precisely the top rğ‘Ÿr eigenvectors of ğ—ğ—T/Nsuperscriptğ—ğ—ğ‘‡ğ‘\mathbf{X}\mathbf{X}^{T}/N, with corresponding eigenvalues â€–xâ€–2â€‹Ïâ€‹[â„“]superscriptnormğ‘¥2ğœŒdelimited-[]â„“\|x\|^{2}\rho[\ell]. Then,Â (V.2) tells us exactly how well we expect the spectral algorithm to perform in recovering xğ‘¥x; indeed, the theory predicts a non-zero angle between xğ‘¥x and the top eigenvector of ğ˜ğ˜T/Nsuperscriptğ˜ğ˜ğ‘‡ğ‘\mathbf{Y}\mathbf{Y}^{T}/N whenever:

Nâ‰¥Lâ€‹Ïƒ4â€–xâ€–4â€‹(maxâ¡Ï)2=L(maxâ¡Ï)2â€‹1SNR2.ğ‘ğ¿superscriptğœ4superscriptnormğ‘¥4superscriptğœŒ2ğ¿superscriptğœŒ21superscriptSNR2\displaystyle N\geq\frac{L\sigma^{4}}{\|x\|^{4}(\max\rho)^{2}}=\frac{L}{(\max\rho)^{2}}\frac{1}{\operatorname{SNR}^{2}}. (V.5)

Below this threshold, the output will be essentially random. We see that if the distribution is well-localized, then maxâ¡Ï=Î©â€‹(1)ğœŒÎ©1\max\rho=\Omega(1) (with respect to the growing value of Lğ¿L) and then the sample complexity grows like LSNR2ğ¿superscriptSNR2\frac{L}{\operatorname{SNR}^{2}}. On the other hand, if the distribution is almost uniform, then maxâ¡Ï=ğ’ªâ€‹(1/L)ğœŒğ’ª1ğ¿\max\rho=\mathcal{O}(1/L) as Lâ†’âˆâ†’ğ¿L\to\infty, and thus the sample complexity will be proportional to L3/SNR2superscriptğ¿3superscriptSNR2L^{3}/\operatorname{SNR}^{2}.

To illustrate the relationship between the spiked model and MRA, we ran the following experiment. We generated a signal xâˆˆâ„400ğ‘¥superscriptâ„400x\in\mathbb{R}^{400} with i.i.d.Â normal entries and normalized it so that â€–xâ€–2=10subscriptnormğ‘¥210\|x\|_{2}=10. For noise levels Ïƒğœ\sigma between 0.1 and 10, we drew Nğ‘N samples of xğ‘¥x with noise at level Ïƒğœ\sigma, where Nğ‘N is chosen at 100 plus the critical threshold given byÂ (V.5) for Ïƒ=Î»1/2â€‹Î³âˆ’1/4=5.5313ğœsuperscriptğœ†12superscriptğ›¾145.5313\sigma=\lambda^{1/2}\gamma^{-1/4}=5.5313 according toÂ (V.3). For Ïƒğœ\sigma large enough, Nğ‘N will not be large enough for the spectral method to produce an estimate better than random. The distribution of translations ÏğœŒ\rho was taken to be Ïâ€‹[i]âˆi2proportional-toğœŒdelimited-[]ğ‘–superscriptğ‘–2\rho[i]\propto i^{2}, for i=1,â€¦,5ğ‘–1â€¦5i=1,\dots,5, and zero elsewhere. Each experiment was repeated 200 times. The plots in FigureÂ V.1 display the average values over these 200 runs.

For each draw, we compute the top eigenvalue of the clean data matrixÂ (V.4), denoted by Î»ğœ†\lambda, and the associated eigenvector, which is a translated copy of xğ‘¥x. We also compute the top eigenvector of the data matrix ğ˜ğ˜T/Nsuperscriptğ˜ğ˜ğ‘‡ğ‘\mathbf{Y}\mathbf{Y}^{T}/N. The angle between the two eigenvectors is predicted byÂ (V.2). In FigureÂ 1(a), we plot the predicted cosine against the true cosine. Clearly, we never attain the predicted value of zero in finite samples, but we see a precipitous decline when the noise level Ïƒğœ\sigma exceeds its threshold value (the vertical dashed line).

We also measure the relative mean squared error defined by equationÂ (I.2), where X^^ğ‘‹\widehat{X} is the top eigenvector multiplied by â€–xâ€–normğ‘¥\|x\|. In FigureÂ 1(b), we plot this error as a function of Ïƒğœ\sigma. For reference, we also plot the ordinary error predicted by the spiked model (as derived from the predicted cosine between the vectors), without minimizing over shifts. Of course, minimizing over shifts will decrease the error; however, we still see the same qualitative behavior predicted from the spiked model, namely an increase in error as Ïƒğœ\sigma grows, until the critical threshold of Ïƒğœ\sigma is reached, after which the error plateaus.

VI Additional Algorithms

While the spectral algorithm (Algorithm 2) is asymptotically optimal as Ïƒğœ\sigma, Nâ†’âˆâ†’ğ‘N\to\infty and for signals with non-vanishing DFTDFT\operatorname{DFT}, it may not perform well in small sample size or low DFTDFT\operatorname{DFT} values. Therefore, in this section, we present two additional algorithms based on non-convex LS minimization and a modification of the EM algorithm presented in SectionÂ II that takes the distribution into account. In AppendixÂ -L, we also describe and analyze a convex relaxation approach based on semidefinite programming.

VI-A Non-convex least-squares minimization

The following method aims to find a signal in â„Lsuperscriptâ„ğ¿\mathbb{R}^{L} and a distribution in Î”LsuperscriptÎ”ğ¿\Delta^{L} that fit the observed data as well as possible in the LS sense. We formulate the problem as a smooth, non-convex, optimization problem with the constraint that the distribution lies on a simplex. Given estimators M^1superscript^ğ‘€1\widehat{M}\phantom{M}^{1} and M^2superscript^ğ‘€2\widehat{M}\phantom{M}^{2} of the first two moments M1superscriptğ‘€1M^{1} and M2superscriptğ‘€2M^{2}, the problem reads

minx~âˆˆâ„L,Ï~âˆˆÎ”Lâ¡â€–M^2âˆ’Cx~â€‹DÏ~â€‹Cx~Tâ€–F2+Î»â€‹â€–M^1âˆ’Cx~â€‹Ï~â€–22,subscriptformulae-sequence~ğ‘¥superscriptâ„ğ¿~ğœŒsuperscriptÎ”ğ¿superscriptsubscriptnormsuperscript^ğ‘€2subscriptğ¶~ğ‘¥subscriptğ·~ğœŒsuperscriptsubscriptğ¶~ğ‘¥ğ‘‡F2ğœ†superscriptsubscriptnormsuperscript^ğ‘€1subscriptğ¶~ğ‘¥~ğœŒ22\min_{\tilde{x}\in\mathbb{R}^{L},\tilde{\rho}\in\Delta^{L}}\|\widehat{M}\phantom{M}^{2}-C_{\tilde{x}}D_{\tilde{\rho}}C_{\tilde{x}}^{T}\|_{\textrm{F}}^{2}+\lambda\|\widehat{M}\phantom{M}^{1}-C_{\tilde{x}}\tilde{\rho}\|_{2}^{2}, (VI.1)

where Î»>0ğœ†0\lambda>0 is a predefined parameter. It can be verified that, by omitting signal-dependent terms, the variance of the elements of the first moment estimator is proportional to Ïƒ2superscriptğœ2\sigma^{2}. It can be also shown that the variance of the elements of the second moment is proportional to 3â€‹Lâ€‹Ïƒ43ğ¿superscriptğœ43L\sigma^{4} and Lâ€‹Ïƒ2ğ¿superscriptğœ2L\sigma^{2} in the low and the high SNRSNR\operatorname{SNR} regimes, respectively (again, by omitting signal-dependent terms)Â [38]. Therefore, we set Î»=1Lâ€‹(1+3â€‹Ïƒ2)ğœ†1ğ¿13superscriptğœ2\lambda=\frac{1}{L(1+3\sigma^{2})} in our implementation.

VII Numerical experiments

In this section, we present numerical results for the algorithms described in SectionÂ VI and AlgorithmÂ 2. To measure the accuracy of an estimator X^^ğ‘‹\widehat{X}, we define the recovery relative error as

relative error=minsâˆˆâ„¤Lâ¡â€–Rsâ€‹X^âˆ’xâ€–2â€–xâ€–2.relative errorsubscriptğ‘ subscriptâ„¤ğ¿subscriptnormsubscriptğ‘…ğ‘ ^ğ‘‹ğ‘¥2subscriptnormğ‘¥2\textrm{relative error}=\min_{s\in\mathbb{Z}_{L}}\frac{\|R_{s}\widehat{X}-x\|_{2}}{\|x\|_{2}}. (VII.1)

The code of this section, including Matlab implementations and examples, is publicly available onlineÂ 111https://github.com/nirsharon/aperiodicMRA.

VII-A Influence of the number of samples

In the first example, we use a Haar-like signal of length L=20ğ¿20L=20, depicted in FigureÂ 1(a). Next, we generate its noisy, translated copies according to the MRA modelÂ (I.1), with noise variance of Ïƒ=.25ğœ.25\sigma=.25. One example of a data sample corrupted with such noise is illustrated in FigureÂ 1(b).

We use the EM algorithm of SectionÂ VI-B to estimate the signal. This process is repeated three times for different number of samples, N=103ğ‘superscript103N=10^{3}, N=105ğ‘superscript105N=10^{5}, and N=107ğ‘superscript107N=10^{7}. The estimates are presented in FigureÂ 1(c)â€“1(e). As expected, the quality of the estimation improves significantly as Nğ‘N grows.

VII-B Comparison of EM algorithms

InÂ [17], it is shown that in most cases, an EM method as described in SectionÂ II-B, achieves the smallest estimation error compared to the competitor algorithms. The EM algorithm described in that paper is invariant to the distribution ÏğœŒ\rho. In particular, it treats the data as if it were drawn from the uniform distribution, which requires sample complexity that grows like Ï‰â€‹(1/SNR3)ğœ”1superscriptSNR3\omega(1/\operatorname{SNR}^{3}) rather than Ï‰â€‹(1/SNR2)ğœ”1superscriptSNR2\omega(1/\operatorname{SNR}^{2}). By contrast, the EM algorithm we propose in SectionÂ VI-B also estimates the distribution ÏğœŒ\rho at each iteration. The updated estimation of the distribution is then used to update the signalâ€™s estimation.

To demonstrate the importance of including the distribution into the model of the estimator, we consider a family of distributions

Ïâ€‹[t]âˆexpâ¡(âˆ’t2/s2)proportional-toğœŒdelimited-[]ğ‘¡superscriptğ‘¡2superscriptğ‘ 2\rho[t]\propto\exp(-t^{2}/s^{2}) (VII.2)

where the parameter s>0ğ‘ 0s>0 controls the concentration of ÏğœŒ\rho, or alternatively its uniformity: the larger sğ‘ s is, the more uniform ÏğœŒ\rho is. In general, we expect our algorithms to provide better estimations when sğ‘ s is smaller, i.e., when ÏğœŒ\rho is more concentrated; see SectionÂ V.

We compared the standard EM with the EM algorithm described in SectionÂ VI-B. The experiments were conducted as follows. We fixed a random signal of length L=25ğ¿25L=25 with i.i.d.Â normal entries and unit norm, and a series of distributions of the formÂ (VII.2) with the parameter sğ‘ s varying between 333 and 999. Then, for each distribution we generated N=2,000ğ‘2000N=2,000 samples drawn with a fixed level of noise Ïƒ=1ğœ1\sigma=1. We repeated the experiment independently 202020 times and averaged the errors. In FigureÂ VII.2, we plot the relative errors of the methods as a function of the uniformity parameter sğ‘ s. As expected, the standard EM is invariant to sğ‘ s. On the other hand, the adapted version of the EM exploits the varying distribution and performs better under more concentrated distributions. As the distribution becomes more uniform, the two methods exhibit similar error rates.

VII-C Comparison of the different methods

This paper presents three alternative techniques for solving the MRA: the spectral method described in AlgorithmÂ 2, the LS optimization of SectionÂ VI-A, and the EM of SectionÂ VI-B. In this comparison, we examined the estimation error of these three methods with different noise levels. We use a random signal of length L=15ğ¿15L=15 with i.i.d. normal entries and rescaled to unit norm. The distribution ÏğœŒ\rho is obtained by normalizing a vector with i.i.d. entries, distributed uniformly in [0,1]01[0,1]. We fix the number of samples to be N=100,000ğ‘100000N=100,000. Then, we sample the level of noise Ïƒğœ\sigma at 202020 points ranging from 0.010.010.01 to 101010. In FigureÂ VII.3 we plot the average error for each of the sampled points over 40 different values of xğ‘¥x and ÏğœŒ\rho. As can be seen, the LS and EM methods are more robust to noise than the spectral method. In addition, the gap between these two methods becomes small as the SNR decreases.

VII-D Numerical error rates for the EM algorithm

When the distribution ÏğœŒ\rho is aperiodic, the optimal MSE for recovering xğ‘¥x in the low SNR, and large Nğ‘N regime is of size Oâ€‹(Ïƒ4/N)ğ‘‚superscriptğœ4ğ‘O(\sigma^{4}/N). Since the relative error scales as MSEMSE\sqrt{\mathrm{MSE}}, by (VII.1), if the log\log-error is viewed as a function of logâ¡(Ïƒ)ğœ\log(\sigma), the slope is expected to be no smaller than 222 when Ïƒğœ\sigma is large.

In FigureÂ VII.4 we plot the average log-error of the EM algorithm over 300300300 trials as a function of logâ¡(Ïƒ)ğœ\log(\sigma). In each trial, we used the EM algorithm to estimate a randomly generated signal, with translations drawn from a randomly generated probability distribution. When Ïƒğœ\sigma is large, the curve is indeed a line with slope close to 222, which is the expected rate. However, when Ïƒğœ\sigma is small, the curve is a line with slope close to 111; namely, the error behaves approximately like Oâ€‹(Ïƒ/N)ğ‘‚ğœğ‘O(\sigma/\sqrt{N}), rather than Oâ€‹(Ïƒ2/N)ğ‘‚superscriptğœ2ğ‘O(\sigma^{2}/\sqrt{N}). The moderate slope for high SNR suggests that in this regime the recovery problem is easier; for example, we know that alignment is possible in high SNR, as described in SectionÂ II-A.

In FigureÂ VII.5 we plot the average log-error (again over 300300300 experiments) as a function of logâ¡(Ïƒ)ğœ\log(\sigma), but in this case each experiment used the uniform distribution of translations. In this regime, we know fromÂ [18] that the optimal slope is 3, not 2; and indeed, when Ïƒğœ\sigma is large the curve has slope close to 333. As in the other plot, when Ïƒğœ\sigma is small the curve has slope close to 111. Taken together, these two experiments suggest that the EM algorithm exhibits near-optimal behavior for both periodic and aperiodic distributions.

VIII Discussion

In this paper, we have shown that the sample complexity for MRA with an aperiodic distribution of translations grows like Ï‰â€‹(1/SNR2)ğœ”1superscriptSNR2\omega(1/\operatorname{SNR}^{2}). This sample complexity can be achieved by a simple spectral algorithm. We also examined empirically the LS and EM algorithms. Additionally, we extended previous works by showing that the sample complexity for any periodic distribution scales as Ï‰â€‹(1/SNR3)ğœ”1superscriptSNR3\omega(1/\operatorname{SNR}^{3}).

We drew connections between the MRA problem and the spiked covariance model. This connection implies that the sample complexity is inversely proportional to the square of the maximal value of the distribution. Therefore, the more uniform the distribution is, the higher the sample complexity of the problem.

One of the motivations for considering the MRA model arises from the imaging technique called single particle cryoâ€“electron microscopy (cryoâ€“EM), allowing to visualize molecules at near-atomic resolutionÂ [12, 13]. In cryoâ€“EM, noisy two-dimensional tomographic projections of the three-dimensional underlying molecule, taken at unknown viewing direction, are collected. The distribution of viewing directions in cryoâ€“EM is typically non-uniform, as many molecules exhibit some preferred orientation [44].

The MRA modelÂ (I.1) can be thought of as a simplified model for the cryoâ€“EM problem, where cyclic translations replace actions of elements of the group Sâ€‹Oâ€‹(3)ğ‘†ğ‘‚3SO(3) [14]. The tomographic projection does not appear inÂ (I.1). Our technique for MRA, based on the low-order moments of the data, is similar to the framework proposed by Zvi Kam inÂ [45, 46] for cryoâ€“EM. In particular, Kam suggested a method to estimate a molecule directly from the statistics of the projections, rather than estimating the viewing directions. Our work is one step towards understanding the sample complexity of Kamâ€™s method in particular, and the cryoâ€“EM problem in general.

-L Convex relaxation with semidefinite program

In this section, we propose an additional algorithm for non-uniform MRA based on a semidefinite program (SDP) relaxation.

Since the power spectrum of the signal can be estimated from the data at sample complexity scaling as Ï‰â€‹(1/SNR2)ğœ”1superscriptSNR2\omega(1/\operatorname{SNR}^{2}) according toÂ (IV.6), we assume in this section, without loss of generality, that |Fâ€‹x|â€‹[k]=1ğ¹ğ‘¥delimited-[]ğ‘˜1|Fx|[k]=1 for all kğ‘˜k. Note, that as in AlgorithmÂ 2, the normalization is done on the second moment matrix, not the individual observations, in order to retain the noise statistics.
